DOC.brief_summary: It is hypothesized that using methylnaltrexone in addition to pain killer narcotics (opiates) in patients will result in increased tube feeding rates with more frequent nutrition at goal calorie rate.
DOC.brief_title: Effect of Methylnaltrexone (Relistor) on Digestion and Tolerance to Tube Feeding in Patients Treated With Opiates
DOC.detailed_description: Tube feeding rates and tube feeding residual volumes will be measured and followed blinded to the treatment arm (methylnaltrexone vs. placebo) to evaluate if patients (who prior to study entry did not tolerate goal rates tube feeds) can get closer to tube feeding goal with the treatment arm.
DOC.criteria: Inadequate tube feeding rate of greater than equal to 40% below goal rate. Prescribed opiate therapy for pain or sedation, stable dose for minimum 48 hours Stable dose or no dose laxative for minimum 72 hours Unstable Hemodynamics (eg. vasopressor medication) Pregnancy End stage Renal Disease on Dialysis Plan to wean opiates in next 48 hours Known or suspected mechanical gastrointestinal obstruction Initial expired hydrogen breath level greater than 20
DOC.keyword: Hydrogen breath test value and gastric residual volume measurements
Tube feeding tolerance while taking a stable dose of opiate
